sections.name: Why Does Molang Exist?
content: Molang is a simple expression-based language designed for fast, data-driven calculation of values at run-time, and with a direct connection to in-game values and systems.  Its focus is to enable low-level systems like animation to support flexible data-driven behavior for both internal and external creators, while staying highly performant.

sections.name: Lexical Structure
content: The language structure is largely based on simple 'C' language family style syntax.  An expression can be made of either one simple value or math calculation, or can be made of several sub-expressions where more complicated code is required.
In simple cases, the terminating `;` is omitted and the expression result is returned.

In complex cases, multiple sub-expressions are each terminated with a semicolon `;`.  Complex expressions evaluate to `0.0` unless there is a `return` statement, in which case the evaluated value of the `return`'s sub-expression will be returned out of the current scope.

sections.name: Case Sensitivity
content: All things in Molang are case-INsensitive, with the exception of strings, which maintain the case provided.

sections.name: Keywords
content: All identifiers not in a scope listed below are reserved for future use

rows.Description: Numerical constant value
Logical operators
Basic math operators
Parentheses for expression term evaluation control
Braces for execution scope
Null coalescing operator, for handling missing variables or stale actor references
A reference to a geometry named in the entity definition
A reference to a material named in the entity definition
A reference to a texture named in the entity definition
Various math functions
Access to an entity's properties
Read/write storage on an actor
Read/write temporary storage
Read-only storage provided by the game in certain scenarios
Binary conditional operator
Ternary conditional operator - NOTE: Nested ternary expressions without parentheses were incorrectly parsed before a Versioned Change was made to fix it (see 'Versioned Changes' below)
The current value that this expression will ultimately write to (context specific)
For complex expressions, this evaluates the following statement and stops execution of the expression, returns the value computed
Arrow operator, for accessing data from a different entity
For repeating one or more commands 'n' times
For iterating over an array of entities
For early exiting a loop/for_each scope
For skipping the rest of the set of statements of a loop/for_each iteration and moving to the next iteration
Brackets for array access

sections.name: Operator Precedence
content: Molang Operators follow this order to determine which thing is evaluated first when no parentheses are used. This should match the behavior of C or C++. Operators that are higher in this table are evaluated first, while operators on the same row are evaluated with the same priority. When operators have the same priority, they are evaluated left-to-right, except for the Ternary conditional operator, which is evaluated right-to-left. Using parentheses will allow direct control of order of evaluation, and is recommended for more complex expressions.

rows.Description: Higher precedence operators are evaluated first when no parentheses are used to control evaluation order
The Logical Not '!' operator
Multiplication '*' and Division '/'
Addition '+' and Subtraction '-'
Comparison operators '<' '<=' '>' '>=' (See 'Versioned Changes' below)
Equality checking operators '==' '!=' (See 'Versioned Changes' below)
The Logical AND '&&' operator (See 'Versioned Changes' below)
The Logical OR '||' operator (See 'Versioned Changes' below)
Ternary conditional operators using '? :'. Evaluated right-to-left when there are multiple ternary operators. (See 'Versioned Changes' below)
Null coalescing operator '??'
Lower precedence operators are evaluated last when no parentheses are used to control evaluation order

sections.name: Variables
content: There are three variable lifetimes a variable may belong to: Temporary, Entity, and Context:

- Temporary variables (eg: `temp.moo = 1;`) are read/write and valid for the scope they are defined in, as per C rules.  For performance reasons their lifetime is global to the current expression execution and may return a valid value outside of the outermost scope they are defined in for an expression.  Be careful in complex expressions.  We will be adding content errors for invalid accesses as soon as possible.

- Entity variables (eg: `variable.moo = 1;`) are read/write and store their value on the entity for the lifetime of that entity.  Note that these are currently not saved, so quitting and reloading the world will re-initialize these.  In the same way, if the entity is despawned, any variables on the entity will be lost.

- Context variables (eg: `context.moo`) are read-only and specified by the game in certain situations. Details on what variables are specified and when will be available in the documentation of the area where that Molang expression is used (such as behaviors defining what context variables they expose).

sections.name: Values
content: - Boolean values such as actor flags are converted and stored as a float value of either 0.0 or 1.0 for values of false or true respectively.
- For boolean tests, a float value equivalent to 0.0 is false, and anything not equal to 0.0 is true.
- For array indices, floats are C-style-cast to ints, and clamped at zero for negative values or wrapped by the array size for large values.
- Errors (such as divide by zero, missing variables, null references, etc) generally return a value of 0.0.

sections.name: Query Functions
content: Query functions (eg: `query.is_baby` or `query.is_item_equipped('main_hand')`) allow expressions to read game data.  If a query function takes no arguments, do not use parentheses. Otherwise, use parentheses and separate arguments with commas. For a full list of query functions, see below.

sections.name: Aliases
content: To reduce typing burden and increase clarity when reading and writing Molang, the following keyword aliases can make life a bit easier.  Note that left and right sides function identically.

sections.name: Alias Mapping
content: Either syntax will work, and can be intermixed as desired. eg:

sections.name: Structs
content: Structures of data, unlike C, are implicitly defined by usage.  Their purpose is to more efficiently pass data around, such as passing `v.location` rather than `v.x`, `v.y`, and `v.z`.  eg:
For some more usage examples, each of the following expressions return 1.23
v.cowcow.friend = v.pigpig; v.pigpig->v.test.a.b.c = 1.23; v.moo = v.cowcow.friend->v.test; return v.moo.a.b.c;
v.cowcow.friend = v.pigpig; v.pigpig->v.test.a.b.c = 1.23; v.moo = v.cowcow.friend->v.test.a; return v.moo.b.c;
v.cowcow.friend = v.pigpig; v.pigpig->v.test.a.b.c = 1.23; v.moo = v.cowcow.friend->v.test.a.b; return v.moo.c;
v.cowcow.friend = v.pigpig; v.pigpig->v.test.a.b.c = 1.23; v.moo = v.cowcow.friend->v.test.a.b.c; return v.moo;

Note that structures can be arbitrarily deep in their nesting/recursiveness.  That said, it is recommended that you don't copy full structures inside other structures to avoid exploding memory, and not making structures too deep as there is a slight performance cost for each layer.

sections.name: Strings
content: Strings in Molang are surrounded by single quotes, eg: `'minecraft:pig'` or `'hello world!'`. An empty string is defined as two consecutive single quotes.  String operations only support `==` and `!=` at this time.
Note: strings don't support the ' character as there is no support for escape characters at this time.

rows.Description: Absolute value of value
arccos of value
arcsin of value
arctan of value
arctan of y/x.  NOTE: the order of arguments!
Round value up to nearest integral number
Clamp value to between min and max inclusive
Cosine (in degrees) of value
returns the sum of 'num' random numbers, each with a value from low to high`.  Note: the generated random numbers are not integers like normal dice.  For that, use `math.die_roll_integer`.
returns the sum of 'num' random integer numbers, each with a value from low to high`.  Note: the generated random numbers are integers like normal dice.
Calculates e to the value'th power
Round value down to nearest integral number
Useful for simple smooth curve interpolation using one of the Hermite Basis functions: `3t^2 - 2t^3`.  Note that while any valid float is a valid input, this function works best in the range [0,1].
Lerp from start to end via 0_to_1
Lerp the shortest direction around a circle from start degrees to end degrees via 0_to_1
Natural logarithm of value
Return highest value of A or B
Return lowest value of A or B
Minimize angle magnitude (in degrees) into the range [-180, 180)
Return the remainder of value / denominator
Returns the float representation of the constant pi.
Elevates `base` to the `exponent`'th power
Random value between low and high inclusive
Random integer value between low and high inclusive
Round value to nearest integral number
Sine (in degrees) of value
Square root of value
Round value towards zero

sections.name: ->  Arrow Operator
content: Some return values of query function, or values stored in temp/entity/context variables can be a reference to another entity.  The `->` operator allows an expression to access variables or run queries on that entity.  For example, the example below will find all pigs within four meters of the current entity (including itself if it's a pig), and increment a variable `v.x` on itself if the block immediately above each pig is flammable (such as an oak button) :

Note that in the case where the left-hand side of the `->` operator has an error (value is null, the entity was killed previously, or some other issue), the expression will not evaluate the right-hand side and will return 0. This implementation style was a choice between performance and not requiring content creators to overly worry about checking for potentially bad values everywhere.

sections.name: Public Variables
content: In general, variables of a mob are considered private to that mob and cannot be accessed by another.  To expose read-only access of a variable to other mobs, you need to set the 'public' setting on that variable in the owning entity's resource definition.  It is also recommended to default-initialize the variable.

sections.name: { } Brace Scope Delimiters
content: One can group a series of statements into a single group by wrapping them in `{` and `}` symbols.  This is used primarily in loops and conditional statements:

sections.name: Conditionals
content: The conditional '?' operator allows for two convenient ways to implement simple branching logic.
The first way is to use '?' by itself to conditionally execute part of an expression, for example `A ? B`. The part after the '?' is only run if the part before it evaluates to a true boolean.

The second way is to use '?' with a ':' as a 'conditional ternary', for example `A ? B : C`. If the part before the '?' is evaluated as true, the part before the ':' is returned. Otherwise the part after is returned.
NOTE: Nested ternary expressions without parentheses were incorrectly parsed before a Versioned Change was made to fix it (see 'Versioned Changes' below).

sections.name: loop
content: Sometimes you want to execute an expression multiple times.  Rather than copy-pasting it a bunch, you can use `loop(<count>, <expression>);`.  We have placed some arbitrary restrictions on these for safety for now. The maximum loop counter is (as of this document being written) 1024.  Also, note that while you can nest loops inside loops pretty much as deep as you want, be careful you don't make a loop so long it will hang your game.

sections.name: for_each
content: `query.get_nearby_entities` (see below) returns an array of entities.  In order to iterate through them, you can use the following new built-in function `for_each`.  It takes three parameters: `for_each(<variable>, <array>, <expression>);`  The variable can be any variable, either a `temp.` or `variable.`, although I'd recommend using `temp.` to not pollute the entity's variable space.  The expression is any Molang expression you want to execute for each entry in the array)

sections.name: break
content: This will exit out of a `loop` or `for_each` early.  Eg:
loop(10, {t.x = v.x + v.y; v.x = v.y; v.y = t.x; (v.y > 20) ? break;});
This will immediately exit the inner-most active loop, as per C-style language rules.  If you have:

The `break` statement will terminate the inner loop when `v.x > 5`, and continue processing the outer loop's expression.  Note that as v.x is not reset between the outer loops, the second time into the inner loop this will add one more to `v.x` and then exit the inner loop again, resulting in a final value of `v.x` of `6 + 1 + 1 + 1 + ... + 1` = `15`.)

sections.name: continue
content: `continue` functions as per C-style language rules.  Currently only supported in `loop` and `for_each`, this will skip to the next iteration of the current loop.  See `break` above for more details on inner/outer loops.  The following example will result in v.x becoming 6.0, as the increment will be skipped once it reaches that value.  Note that it is better to break out of the loop in this contrived example, as it would be more performant than continuing to perform all 10 iterations.

sections.name: ?? Null Coalescing Operator
content: Similar to how the null-coalescing operator works in C#, one can now reference a variable that may or may not exist without seeing a content error.  If it doesn't, you can now provide a default value to use.  Previously, if a variable didn't exist you would get a content error.  This was to make sure variables were always initialized correctly to avoid uninitialized variable bugs.  Unfortunately this then required initialize scripts, or in some cases some complex work-arounds to make sure variables were initialized.  Now, if you know a variable won't be initialized in the first run of a script, you can use the following:
This will use the value of `variable.x` if it is valid, or else 1.2 if `variable.x`:
- is a reference to a deleted entity

Note that the `??` operator will work with `variable.`s, `temp.`s, and `context.`s that hold numbers or entity references, but not resources such as materials, textures, or geometries (as those must exist and be valid else it's a content error).  If the first argument would result in something that can't be resolved, it will return the second argument.

_Reminder: the standing rule of thumb in Molang is that if something would error or be a bad value, it is converted to 0.0 (and generally throw a content error on screen in non-publish builds.  Note that content errors may prevent uploading content to the Marketplace, so please ensure expressions aren't going to do bad things such as dividing by zero)._

sections.name: Simple vs Complex Expressions
content: A simple expression is a single statement, the value of which is returned to the system that evaluated the expression.  eg:

A complex expression is one with multiple statements, each ending in a ';'.  Each statement is evaluated in order.  In the current implementation, the last statement requires the use of the return keyword and defines the resulting value of the expression.  eg:

Note that in a simple expression, `;` is not allowed, whereas in a complex expression, each statement requires a `;` including the last.  Also, note that if you don't `return` a value from a complex expression, the expression will evaluate to 0.0.

sections.name: Entity Definition Scripts
content: In the definition file there is a section for pre-computing values.  These are executed immediately before animation and render controllers are processed, and stored in the entity.  The purpose is to pre-compute any expensive and complex values you may want to reuse in your scripts, long-living index variable updates, or generally any one-off computation per render tick.

sections.name: Animation and Animation Controller Files
content: These are numerical operations to control which animations are playing and how to animate bones.  "variable.variable_name" and "query.function_name" refer to the entity currently being rendered.  They have access to everything in the language except material, texture, and geometry types.

sections.name: Render Controllers
content: There are a few different kinds of expressions here, where context implies what is allowed.  As with animations, the entity accessors refer to the current entity, however depending on the context one also has access to materials, textures, and geometries.  There are two sections in a render controller:
The array definition section allows you to create arrays of resources by resource type if you so desire.  These can then be referenced in the resource usage section.

sections.name: Array Expressions
content: For each of the three resource types (materials, textures, and geometry), you can define an array of resources.  The name of the resource is the nice-name from the definition file.  Using materials as an example:
Note that all elements of an array must be of the same type.  eg: a texture array must only contain textures.

An array can reference any combination of zero or more arrays (including duplicates if desired) and/or zero or more materials (again, including duplicates if you like), and you can have as many arrays as you like, each with as many elements as you like.  If an array includes arrays in its members, they do not need to be the same length.  When indexing into an array in the resource usage section, you use numerical expressions.  If the resulting number is negative, it will use zero as the index.  Any non - negative index will converted to an integer, and will wrap based on the size of the array:

sections.name: Resource Expression
content: A resource expression must return a single resource of a specific type depending on the context.
For example, in the "geometry" section, you must produce an expression that will result in a single geometry.  Some examples:
Cycle through an array of geometries at a rate of one per second
Pick a geo based on an entity flag
Use specific geo when sleeping, otherwise flip through an array based on a cosine curve, using index zero for almost half the time while the cosine curve is negative

sections.name: Geometry
content: The geometry section specifies which geometry to use when rendering.  As you can specify as many render controllers as you like in the definition file, a single render controller is only concerned with how to render a single geometry.  Note that a geometry can be arbitrarily complex using any number of bones and polygons.

sections.name: Materials
content: The materials section specifies how to map what material to what bone of the geometry.  A single material is mapped to a whole bone.  Material expressions are evaluated in the order listed.  The first part of each statement is the name of the model part to apply the material to, and the second part is the material to use.  The model part name can use * for wild - card matching of characters.  For example:
- This will start by applying Material.default to all model parts.

- Next, it will set the material on a model part named "TailA" to the result of the expression "Array.hairColors[variable.hair_color]".  This will look up some previously created variable on the entity named hair_color and use that to index into a material array called "array.hair_colors" defined in this render controller.  This will overwrite the Material.default material set in the line above.
- Third, it will look up the same material as the expression is identical, and apply it to the "Mane" model part.

- Lastly, if will find any model part starting with, ending with, or containing "Saddle" (case sensitive) and change its material to either material.leather_saddle or material.iron_saddle depending on the previously set entity variable variable.is_leather_saddle.

sections.name: Query Functions
content: Query Functions are operators that access a wide variety of information. They can return simple true or false values (1.0 or 0.0) or more complex data. See the list of functions below for per-query documentation. Query Functions might not take any parameters. In that case, just `query.function_name` is used. Otherwise parentheses with commas separating arguments should be used, ie `query.function_name(1, 2, 'three')`. For example:

rows.Name: query.above_top_solid
rows.Description: Returns the height of the block immediately above the highest solid block at the input (x,z) position

rows.Name: query.actor_count
rows.Description: Returns the number of actors rendered in the last frame.

rows.Name: query.all
rows.Description: Requires at least 3 arguments. Evaluates the first argument, then returns 1.0 if all of the following arguments evaluate to the same value as the first. Otherwise it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.all_animations_finished
rows.Description: Only valid in an animation controller.  Returns 1.0 if all animations in the current animation controller state have played through at least once, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.all_tags
rows.Description: Returns if the item or block has all of the tags specified.

rows.Name: query.anger_level
rows.Description: Returns the anger level of the actor [0,n). On errors or if the actor has no anger level, returns 0. Available on the Server only.

rows.Name: query.anim_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in seconds since the current animation started, else 0.0 if not called within an animation.

rows.Name: query.any
rows.Description: Requires at least 3 arguments. Evaluates the first argument, then returns 1.0 if any of the following arguments evaluate to the same value as the first. Otherwise it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.any_animation_finished
rows.Description: Only valid in an animation controller.  Returns 1.0 if any animation in the current animation controller state has played through at least once, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.any_tag
rows.Description: Returns if the item or block has any of the tags specified.

rows.Name: query.approx_eq
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if all of the arguments are within 0.000000 of each other, else 0.0.

rows.Name: query.armor_color_slot
rows.Description: Takes the armor slot index as a parameter, and returns the color of the armor in the requested slot.

rows.Name: query.armor_material_slot
rows.Description: Takes the armor slot index as a parameter, and returns the armor material type in the requested armor slot.

rows.Name: query.armor_texture_slot
rows.Description: Takes the armor slot index as a parameter, and returns the texture type of the requested slot.

rows.Name: query.average_frame_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in *seconds* of the average frame time over the last 'n' frames.  If an argument is passed, it is assumed to be the number of frames in the past that you wish to query.  'query.average_frame_time' (or the equivalent 'query.average_frame_time(0)') will return the frame time of the frame before the current one.  'query.average_frame_time(1)' will return the average frame time of the previous two frames.  Currently we store the history of the last 30 frames, although note that this may change in the future.  Asking for more frames will result in only sampling the number of frames stored.

rows.Name: query.block_face
rows.Description: Returns the block face for this (only valid for certain triggers such as placing blocks, or interacting with block) (Down=0.0, Up=1.0, North=2.0, South=3.0, West=4.0, East=5.0, Undefined=6.0).

rows.Name: query.block_property
rows.Description: Returns the value of the associated Blocks Block State.

rows.Name: query.blocking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is blocking, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.body_x_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the body pitch rotation if called on an actor, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.body_y_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the body yaw rotation if called on an actor, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.bone_aabb
rows.Description: Returns the axis aligned bounding box of a bone as a struct with members '.min', '.max', along with '.x', '.y', and '.z' values for each.

rows.Name: query.bone_origin
rows.Description: Returns the initial (from the .geo) pivot of a bone as a struct with members '.x', '.y', and '.z'.

rows.Name: query.bone_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the initial (from the .geo) rotation of a bone as a struct with members '.x', '.y', and '.z' in degrees.

rows.Name: query.camera_distance_range_lerp
rows.Description: Takes two distances (any order) and return a number from 0 to 1 based on the camera distance between the two ranges clamped to that range.  For example, 'query.camera_distance_range_lerp(10, 20)' will return 0 for any distance less than or equal to 10, 0.2 for a distance of 12, 0.5 for 15, and 1 for 20 or greater.  If you pass in (20, 10), a distance of 20 will return 0.0.

rows.Name: query.camera_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the rotation of the camera.  Requires one argument representing the rotation axis you would like (0 for x, 1 for y).

rows.Name: query.can_climb
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can climb, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.can_damage_nearby_mobs
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can damage nearby mobs, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.can_dash
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can dash, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.can_fly
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can fly, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.can_power_jump
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can power jump, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.can_swim
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can swim, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.can_walk
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity can walk, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.cape_flap_amount
rows.Description: Returns value between 0.0 and 1.0 with 0.0 meaning cape is fully down and 1.0 is cape is fully up.

rows.Name: query.cardinal_block_face_placed_on
rows.Description: DEPRECATED (please use query.block_face instead) Returns the block face for this (only valid for on_placed_by_player trigger) (Down=0.0, Up=1.0, North=2.0, South=3.0, West=4.0, East=5.0, Undefined=6.0).

rows.Name: query.cardinal_facing
rows.Description: Returns the current facing of the player (Down=0.0, Up=1.0, North=2.0, South=3.0, West=4.0, East=5.0, Undefined=6.0).

rows.Name: query.cardinal_facing_2d
rows.Description: Returns the current facing of the player ignoring up/down part of the direction (North=2.0, South=3.0, West=4.0, East=5.0, Undefined=6.0).

rows.Name: query.cardinal_player_facing
rows.Description: Returns the current facing of the player (Down=0.0, Up=1.0, North=2.0, South=3.0, West=4.0, East=5.0, Undefined=6.0).

rows.Name: query.combine_entities
rows.Description: Combines any valid entity references from all arguments into a single array.  Note that order is not preserved, and duplicates and invalid values are removed.

rows.Name: query.count
rows.Description: Counts the number of things passed to it (arrays are counted as the number of elements they contain; non-arrays count as 1).

rows.Name: query.current_squish_value
rows.Description: Returns the squish value for the current entity, or 0.0 if this doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.dash_cooldown_progress
rows.Description: Returns dash cooldown progress if the entity can dash, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.day
rows.Description: Returns the day of the current level.

rows.Name: query.death_ticks
rows.Description: Returns the elapsed ticks since the mob started dying.

rows.Name: query.debug_output
rows.Description: debug log a value to the output debug window for builds that have one

rows.Name: query.delta_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in seconds since the previous frame.

rows.Name: query.distance_from_camera
rows.Description: Returns the distance of the root of this actor or particle emitter from the camera.

rows.Name: query.effect_emitter_count
rows.Description: Returns the total number of active emitters of the callee's particle effect type.

rows.Name: query.effect_particle_count
rows.Description: Returns the total number of active particles of the callee's particle effect type.

rows.Name: query.equipment_count
rows.Description: Returns the number of equipped armor pieces for an actor from 0 to 4, not counting items held in hands. (To query for hand slots, use query.is_item_equipped or query.is_item_name_any).

rows.Name: query.equipped_item_all_tags
rows.Description: Takes a slot name followed by any tag you want to check for in the form of 'tag_name' and returns 1 if all of the tags are on that equipped item, 0 otherwise.

rows.Name: query.equipped_item_any_tag
rows.Description: Takes a slot name followed by any tag you want to check for in the form of 'tag_name' and returns 0 if none of the tags are on that equipped item or 1 if at least 1 tag exists.

rows.Name: query.equipped_item_is_attachable
rows.Description: Takes the desired hand slot as a parameter (0 or 'main_hand' for main hand, 1 or 'off_hand' for off hand), and returns whether the item is an attachable or not.

rows.Name: query.eye_target_x_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the X eye rotation of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.eye_target_y_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the Y eye rotation of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.facing_target_to_range_attack
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is attacking from range (i.e. minecraft:behavior.ranged_attack), else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.frame_alpha
rows.Description: Returns the ratio (from 0 to 1) of how much between AI ticks this frame is being rendered.

rows.Name: query.get_actor_info_id
rows.Description: Returns the integer id of an actor by its string name.

rows.Name: query.get_animation_frame
rows.Description: Returns the current texture of the item

rows.Name: query.get_default_bone_pivot
rows.Description: Gets specified axis of the specified bone orientation pivot.

rows.Name: query.get_equipped_item_name
rows.Description: DEPRECATED (Use query.is_item_name_any instead if possible so names can be changed later without breaking content.) Takes one optional hand slot as a parameter (0 or 'main_hand' for main hand, 1 or 'off_hand' for off hand), and a second parameter (0=default) if you would like the equipped item or any non-zero number for the currently rendered item, and returns the name of the item in the requested slot (defaulting to the main hand if no parameter is supplied) if there is one, otherwise returns ''.

rows.Name: query.get_locator_offset
rows.Description: Gets specified axis of the specified locator offset.

rows.Name: query.get_name
rows.Description: DEPRECATED (Use query.is_name_any instead if possible so names can be changed later without breaking content.)Get the name of the mob if there is one, otherwise return ''.

rows.Name: query.get_root_locator_offset
rows.Description: Gets specified axis of the specified locator offset of the root model.

rows.Name: query.ground_speed
rows.Description: Returns the ground speed of the entity in meters/second.

rows.Name: query.had_component_group
rows.Description: Usable only in behavior packs when determining the default value for an entity's Property. Requires one string argument. If the entity is being loaded from data that was last saved with a component_group with the specified name, returns 1.0, otherwise returns 0.0. The purpose of this query is to allow entity definitions to change and still be able to load the correct state of entities.

rows.Name: query.has_any_family
rows.Description: Returns 1 if the entity has any of the specified families, else 0.

rows.Name: query.has_armor_slot
rows.Description: Takes the armor slot index as a parameter, and returns 1.0 if the entity has armor in the requested slot, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.has_biome_tag
rows.Description: Returns whether or not a Block Placement Target has a specific biome tag

rows.Name: query.has_block_property
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the associated block has the given block property or 0.0 if not

rows.Name: query.has_cape
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the player has a cape, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.has_collision
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has collisions enabled, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.has_dash_cooldown
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has cooldown on its dash, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.has_gravity
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is affected by gravity, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.has_owner
rows.Description: Returns true if the entity has an owner ID else it returns false

rows.Name: query.has_property
rows.Description: Takes one argument: the name of the property on the Actor. Returns 1.0 if a property with the given name exists, 0 otherwise.

rows.Name: query.has_rider
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has a rider, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.has_target
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has a target, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.head_roll_angle
rows.Description: Returns the roll angle of the head of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.head_x_rotation
rows.Description: Takes one argument as a parameter.  Returns the nth head x rotation of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.head_y_rotation
rows.Description: Takes one argument as a parameter.  Returns the nth head y rotation of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.health
rows.Description: Returns the health of the entity, or 0.0 if it doesn't make sense to call on this entity.

rows.Name: query.heartbeat_interval
rows.Description: Returns the heartbeat interval of the actor in seconds. Returns 0 when the actor has no heartbeat.

rows.Name: query.heartbeat_phase
rows.Description: Returns the heartbeat phase of the actor. 0.0 if at start of current heartbeat, 1.0 if at the end. Returns 0 on errors or when the actor has no heartbeat. Available on the Client (Resource Packs) only.

rows.Name: query.heightmap
rows.Description: Queries Height Map

rows.Name: query.hurt_direction
rows.Description: Returns the hurt direction for the actor, otherwise returns 0.

rows.Name: query.hurt_time
rows.Description: Returns the hurt time for the actor, otherwise returns 0.

rows.Name: query.in_range
rows.Description: Requires 3 numerical arguments: some value, a minimum, and a maximum. If the first argument is between the minimum and maximum (inclusive), returns 1.0. Otherwise returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.invulnerable_ticks
rows.Description: Returns the number of ticks of invulnerability the entity has left if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_admiring
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is admiring, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_alive
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is alive, and 0.0 if it's dead.

rows.Name: query.is_angry
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is angry, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_attached_to_entity
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the actor is attached to an entity, else it will return 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_avoiding_block
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is fleeing from a block, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_avoiding_mobs
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is fleeing from mobs, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_baby
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is a baby, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_breathing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is breathing, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_bribed
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has been bribed, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_carrying_block
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is carrying a block, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_casting
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is casting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_celebrating
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is celebrating, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_celebrating_special
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is doing a special celebration, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_charged
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is charged, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_charging
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is charging, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_chested
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has chests attached to it, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_critical
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is critical, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_croaking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is croaking, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_dancing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is dancing, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_delayed_attacking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is attacking using the delayed attack, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_digging
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is digging, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_eating
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is eating, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_eating_mob
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is eating a mob, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_elder
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is an elder version of it, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_emerging
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is emerging, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_emoting
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is emoting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_enchanted
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is enchanted, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_feeling_happy
rows.Description: [EXPERIMENTAL] Returns 1.0 if the entity is feeling happy, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_fire_immune
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is immune to fire, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_first_person
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is being rendered in first person mode, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_ghost
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if an entity is a ghost, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_gliding
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is gliding, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_grazing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is grazing, or 0.0 if not.

rows.Name: query.is_idling
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is idling, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_ignited
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is ignited, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_illager_captain
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is an illager captain, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_in_contact_with_water
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is in contact with any water (water, rain, splash water bottle), else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_in_love
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is in love, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_in_ui
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is rendered as part of the UI, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_in_water
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is in water, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_in_water_or_rain
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is in water or rain, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_interested
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is interested, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_invisible
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is invisible, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_item_equipped
rows.Description: Takes one optional hand slot as a parameter (0 or 'main_hand' for main hand, 1 or 'off_hand' for off hand), and returns 1.0 if there is an item in the requested slot (defaulting to the main hand if no parameter is supplied), otherwise returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_item_name_any
rows.Description: Takes an equipment slot name (see the replaceitem command) and an optional slot index value. (The slot index is required for slot names that have multiple slots, for example 'slot.hotbar'.) After that, takes one or more full name (with 'namespace:') strings to check for. Returns 1.0 if an item in the specified slot has any of the specified names, otherwise returns 0.0. An empty string '' can be specified to check for an empty slot. Note that querying slot.enderchest, slot.saddle, slot.armor, or slot.chest will only work in behavior packs. A preferred query to query.get_equipped_item_name, as it can be adjusted by Mojang to avoid breaking content if names are changed.

rows.Name: query.is_jump_goal_jumping
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is doing a jump goal jump, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_jumping
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is jumping, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_laying_down
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is laying down, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_laying_egg
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is laying an egg, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_leashed
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is leashed to something, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_levitating
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is levitating, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_lingering
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is lingering, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_local_player
rows.Description: Takes no arguments. Returns 1.0 if the entity is the local player for the current game window, else it returns 0.0. In splitscreen returns 0.0 for the other local players for other views. Always returns 0.0 if used in a behavior pack.

rows.Name: query.is_moving
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is moving, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_name_any
rows.Description: Takes one or more arguments. If the entity's name is any of the specified string values, returns 1.0. Otherwise returns 0.0. A preferred query to query.get_name, as it can be adjusted by Mojang to avoid breaking content if names are changed.

rows.Name: query.is_on_fire
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is on fire, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_on_ground
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is on the ground, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_on_screen
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if this is called on an entity at a time when it is known if it is on screen, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_onfire
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is on fire, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_orphaned
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is orphaned, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_owner_identifier_any
rows.Description: Takes one or more arguments. Returns whether the root actor identifier is any of the specified strings. A preferred query to query.owner_identifier, as it can be adjusted by Mojang to avoid breaking content if names are changed.

rows.Name: query.is_persona_or_premium_skin
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the player has a persona or premium skin, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_playing_dead
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is playing dead, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_powered
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is powered, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_pregnant
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is pregnant, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_ram_attacking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is using a ram attack, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_resting
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is resting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_riding
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is riding, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_rising
rows.Description: [EXPERIMENTAL] Returns 1.0 if the entity is rising, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_roaring
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is currently roaring, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_rolling
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is rolling, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_saddled
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity has a saddle, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_scared
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is scared, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_scenting
rows.Description: [EXPERIMENTAL] Returns 1.0 if the entity is scenting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_searching
rows.Description: [EXPERIMENTAL] Returns 1.0 if the entity is searching, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_selected_item
rows.Description: Returns true if the player has selected an item in the inventory, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_shaking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is casting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_shaking_wetness
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is shaking water off, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sheared
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is able to be sheared and is sheared, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_shield_powered
rows.Description: Returns 1.0f if the entity has an active powered shield if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_silent
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is silent, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sitting
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sitting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sleeping
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sleeping, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sneaking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sneaking, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sneezing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sneezing, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sniffing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sniffing, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sonic_boom
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is using sonic boom, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_spectator
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is spectator, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_sprinting
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is sprinting, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_stackable
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is stackable, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_stalking
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is stalking, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_standing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is standing, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_stunned
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is currently stunned, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_swimming
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is swimming, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_tamed
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is tamed, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_transforming
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is transforming, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_using_item
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is using an item, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_wall_climbing
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is climbing a wall, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.item_in_use_duration
rows.Description: Returns the amount of time an item has been in use in seconds up to the maximum duration, else 0.0 if it doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.item_is_charged
rows.Description: Takes one optional hand slot as a parameter (0 or 'main_hand' for main hand, 1 or 'off_hand' for off hand), and returns 1.0 if the item is charged in the requested slot (defaulting to the main hand if no parameter is supplied), otherwise returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.item_max_use_duration
rows.Description: Returns the maximum amount of time the item can be used, else 0.0 if it doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.item_remaining_use_duration
rows.Description: Returns the amount of time an item has left to use, else 0.0 if it doesn't make sense.Item queried is specified by the slot name 'main_hand' or 'off_hand'.Time remaining is normalized using the normalization value, only if one is given, else it is returned in seconds.

rows.Name: query.item_slot_to_bone_name
rows.Description: query.item_slot_to_bone_name requires one parameter: the name of the equipment slot.  This function returns the name of the bone this entity has mapped to that slot.

rows.Name: query.key_frame_lerp_time
rows.Description: Returns the ratio between the previous and next key frames.

rows.Name: query.last_frame_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in *seconds* of the last frame.  If an argument is passed, it is assumed to be the number of frames in the past that you wish to query.  'query.last_frame_time' (or the equivalent 'query.last_frame_time(0)') will return the frame time of the frame before the current one.  'query.last_frame_time(1)' will return the frame time of two frames ago.  Currently we store the history of the last 30 frames, although note that this may change in the future.  Passing an index more than the available data will return the oldest frame stored.

rows.Name: query.last_hit_by_player
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity was last hit by the player, else it returns 0.0. If called by the client always returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.lie_amount
rows.Description: Returns the lie down amount for the entity.

rows.Name: query.life_span
rows.Description: Returns the limited life span of an entity, or 0.0 if it lives forever

rows.Name: query.life_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in seconds since the current animation started, else 0.0 if not called within an animation.

rows.Name: query.lod_index
rows.Description: Takes an array of distances and returns the zero - based index of which range the actor is in based on distance from the camera. For example, 'query.lod_index(10, 20, 30)' will return 0, 1, or 2 based on whether the mob is less than 10, 20, or 30 units away from the camera, or it will return 3 if it is greater than 30.

rows.Name: query.log
rows.Description: debug log a value to the content log

rows.Name: query.main_hand_item_max_duration
rows.Description: Returns the use time maximum duration for the main hand item if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.main_hand_item_use_duration
rows.Description: Returns the use time for the main hand item.

rows.Name: query.mark_variant
rows.Description: Returns the entity's mark variant

rows.Name: query.max_durability
rows.Description: Returns the max durability an item can take.

rows.Name: query.max_health
rows.Description: Returns the maximum health of the entity, or 0.0 if it doesn't make sense to call on this entity.

rows.Name: query.max_trade_tier
rows.Description: Returns the maximum trade tier of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.maximum_frame_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in *seconds* of the most expensive frame over the last 'n' frames.  If an argument is passed, it is assumed to be the number of frames in the past that you wish to query.  'query.maximum_frame_time' (or the equivalent 'query.maximum_frame_time(0)') will return the frame time of the frame before the current one.  'query.maximum_frame_time(1)' will return the maximum frame time of the previous two frames.  Currently we store the history of the last 30 frames, although note that this may change in the future.  Asking for more frames will result in only sampling the number of frames stored.

rows.Name: query.minimum_frame_time
rows.Description: Returns the time in *seconds* of the least expensive frame over the last 'n' frames.  If an argument is passed, it is assumed to be the number of frames in the past that you wish to query.  'query.minimum_frame_time' (or the equivalent 'query.minimum_frame_time(0)') will return the frame time of the frame before the current one.  'query.minimum_frame_time(1)' will return the minimum frame time of the previous two frames.  Currently we store the history of the last 30 frames, although note that this may change in the future.  Asking for more frames will result in only sampling the number of frames stored.

rows.Name: query.model_scale
rows.Description: Returns the scale of the current entity.

rows.Name: query.modified_distance_moved
rows.Description: Returns the total distance the entity has moved horizontally in meters (since the entity was last loaded, not necessarily since it was originally created) modified along the way by status flags such as is_baby or on_fire.

rows.Name: query.modified_move_speed
rows.Description: Returns the current walk speed of the entity modified by status flags such as is_baby or on_fire.

rows.Name: query.moon_brightness
rows.Description: Returns the brightness of the moon (FULL_MOON=1.0, WANING_GIBBOUS=0.75, FIRST_QUARTER=0.5, WANING_CRESCENT=0.25, NEW_MOON=0.0, WAXING_CRESCENT=0.25, LAST_QUARTER=0.5, WAXING_GIBBOUS=0.75).

rows.Name: query.moon_phase
rows.Description: Returns the phase of the moon (FULL_MOON=0, WANING_GIBBOUS=1, FIRST_QUARTER=2, WANING_CRESCENT=3, NEW_MOON=4, WAXING_CRESCENT=5, LAST_QUARTER=6, WAXING_GIBBOUS=7).

rows.Name: query.movement_direction
rows.Description: Returns the specified axis of the normalized position delta of the entity.

rows.Name: query.noise
rows.Description: Queries Perlin Noise Map

rows.Name: query.on_fire_time
rows.Description: Returns the time that the entity is on fire, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.out_of_control
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if the entity is out of control, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.overlay_alpha
rows.Description: DEPRECATED (Do not use - this function is deprecated and will be removed).

rows.Name: query.owner_identifier
rows.Description: DEPRECATED (Use query.is_owner_identifier_any instead if possible so names can be changed later without breaking content.) Returns the root actor identifier.

rows.Name: query.player_level
rows.Description: Returns the players level if the actor is a player, otherwise returns 0.

rows.Name: query.position
rows.Description: Returns the absolute position of an actor.  Takes one argument that represents the desired axis (0 == x-axis, 1 == y-axis, 2 == z-axis).

rows.Name: query.position_delta
rows.Description: Returns the position delta for an actor.  Takes one argument that represents the desired axis (0 == x-axis, 1 == y-axis, 2 == z-axis).

rows.Name: query.previous_squish_value
rows.Description: Returns the previous squish value for the current entity, or 0.0 if this doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.property
rows.Description: Takes one argument: the name of the property on the entity. Returns the value of that property if it exists, else 0.0 if not.

rows.Name: query.remaining_durability
rows.Description: Returns the how much durability an item has remaining.

rows.Name: query.roll_counter
rows.Description: Returns the roll counter of the entity.

rows.Name: query.rotation_to_camera
rows.Description: Returns the rotation required to aim at the camera.  Requires one argument representing the rotation axis you would like (0 for x, 1 for y).

rows.Name: query.shake_angle
rows.Description: Returns the shaking angle of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.shake_time
rows.Description: Returns the shake time of the entity.

rows.Name: query.shield_blocking_bob
rows.Description: Returns the how much the offhand shield should translate down when blocking and being hit.

rows.Name: query.show_bottom
rows.Description: Returns 1.0 if we render the entity's bottom, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.sit_amount
rows.Description: Returns the current sit amount of the entity.

rows.Name: query.skin_id
rows.Description: Returns the entity's skin ID

rows.Name: query.sleep_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the rotation of the bed the player is sleeping on.

rows.Name: query.sneeze_counter
rows.Description: Returns the sneeze counter of the entity.

rows.Name: query.spellcolor
rows.Description: Returns a struct representing the entity spell color for the specified entity. The struct contains '.r' '.g' '.b' and '.a' members, each 0.0 to 1.0. If no actor is specified, each member value will be 0.0.

rows.Name: query.standing_scale
rows.Description: Returns the scale of how standing up the entity is.

rows.Name: query.structural_integrity
rows.Description: Returns the structural integrity for the actor, otherwise returns 0.

rows.Name: query.surface_particle_color
rows.Description: Returns the particle color for the block located in the surface below the actor (scanned up to 10 blocks down). The struct contains '.r' '.g' '.b' and '.a' members, each 0.0 to 1.0. If no actor is specified or if no surface is found, each member value is set to 0.0. Available on the Client (Resource Packs) only.

rows.Name: query.surface_particle_texture_coordinate
rows.Description: Returns the texture coordinate for generating particles for the block located in the surface below the actor (scanned up to 10 blocks down) in a struct with 'u' and 'v' keys. If no actor is specified or if no surface is found, u and v will be 0.0. Available on the Client (Resource Packs) only.

rows.Name: query.surface_particle_texture_size
rows.Description: Returns the texture size for generating particles for the block located in the surface below the actor (scanned up to 10 blocks down). If no actor is specified or if no surface is found, each member value will be 0.0. Available on the Client (Resource Packs) only.

rows.Name: query.swell_amount
rows.Description: Returns how swollen the entity is.

rows.Name: query.swelling_dir
rows.Description: Returns the swelling direction of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.swim_amount
rows.Description: Returns the amount the current entity is swimming.

rows.Name: query.tail_angle
rows.Description: Returns the angle of the tail of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.target_x_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the x rotation required to aim at the entity's current target if it has one, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.target_y_rotation
rows.Description: Returns the y rotation required to aim at the entity's current target if it has one, else it returns 0.0.

rows.Name: query.texture_frame_index
rows.Description: Returns the icon index of the experience orb.

rows.Name: query.time_of_day
rows.Description: Returns the time of day (midnight=0.0, sunrise=0.25, noon=0.5, sunset=0.75) of the dimension the entity is in.

rows.Name: query.time_since_last_vibration_detection
rows.Description: Returns the time in seconds since the last vibration detected by the actor. On errors or if no vibration has been detected yet, returns -1. Available on the Client (Resource Packs) only.

rows.Name: query.time_stamp
rows.Description: Returns the current time stamp of the level

rows.Name: query.total_emitter_count
rows.Description: Returns the total number of active emitters in the world.

rows.Name: query.total_particle_count
rows.Description: Returns the total number of active particles in the world.

rows.Name: query.trade_tier
rows.Description: Returns the trade tier of the entity if it makes sense, else it returns 0.0

rows.Name: query.unhappy_counter
rows.Description: Returns how unhappy the entity is.

rows.Name: query.variant
rows.Description: Returns the entity's variant index

rows.Name: query.vertical_speed
rows.Description: Returns the speed of the entity up or down in meters/second, where positive is up.

rows.Name: query.walk_distance
rows.Description: Returns the walk distance of the entity.

rows.Name: query.wing_flap_position
rows.Description: Returns the wing flap position of the entity, or 0.0 if this doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.wing_flap_speed
rows.Description: Returns the wing flap speed of the entity, or 0.0 if this doesn't make sense.

rows.Name: query.yaw_speed
rows.Description: Returns the entity's yaw speed

rows.Name: query.biome_has_all_tags
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes either no position (assumes the current entity position) or three parameters: x, y, z (representing the world-origin-relative position), followed by whatever tags you want to query for, and returns 1 if all of them exist in the biome, else it returns 0.  Eg: query.biome_has_all_tags('is_cold', 'has_trees').

rows.Name: query.biome_has_any_tag
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes either no position (assumes the current entity position) or three parameters: x, y, z (representing the world-origin-relative position), followed by whatever tags you want to query for, and returns 1 if any of them exist in the biome, else it returns 0.  Eg: query.biome_has_any_tag('is_cold', 'has_trees').

rows.Name: query.block_has_all_tags
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes a world-origin-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has all of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.block_has_any_tag
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes a world-origin-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has any of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.block_neighbor_has_all_tags
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes a block-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has all of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.block_neighbor_has_any_tag
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes a block-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has any of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.bone_orientation_matrix
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes the name of the bone as an argument. Returns the bone orientation (as a matrix) of the desired bone provided it exists in the queryable geometry of the mob, else this returns the identity matrix and throws a content error.

rows.Name: query.bone_orientation_trs
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) TRS stands for Translate/Rotate/Scale.  Takes the name of the bone as an argument.  Returns the bone orientation matrix decomposed into the component translation/rotation/scale parts of the desired bone provided it exists in the queryable geometry of the mob, else this returns the identity matrix and throws a content error.  The returned value is returned as a variable of type 'struct' with members '.t', '.r', and '.s', each with members '.x', '.y', and '.z', and can be accessed as per the following example: v.my_variable = q.bone_orientation_trs('rightarm'); return v.my_variable.r.x;

rows.Name: query.client_input_type
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns either 'mouse', 'touch', 'gamepad', or 'motion_controller' depending on the type of input used by the current client.

rows.Name: query.cooldown_time
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the total cooldown time in seconds for the item held or worn by the specified equipment slot name (and optional second numerical slot id), otherwise returns 0. Uses the same name and id that the replaceitem command takes when querying entities.

rows.Name: query.cooldown_time_remaining
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the cooldown time remaining in seconds for specified cooldown type or the item held or worn by the specified equipment slot name (and optional second numerical slot id), otherwise returns 0. Uses the same name and id that the replaceitem command takes when querying entities. Returns highest cooldown if no parameters are supplied.

rows.Name: query.get_nearby_entities
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the list of entities within the specified distance, taking an optional second argument as a filter for which mob types to accept (eg: 'minecraft:pig').

rows.Name: query.get_nearby_entities_except_self
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the list of entities within the specified distance, taking an optional second argument as a filter for which mob types to accept (eg: 'minecraft:pig').

rows.Name: query.get_ride
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the entity this entity is riding if it is riding something, else it returns 0.

rows.Name: query.get_riders
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the array of entities that are riding this entity.

rows.Name: query.has_player_rider
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns 1 if the entity has a player riding it, else it returns 0.

rows.Name: query.is_attached
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns 1.0 if the actor is attached to another actor (such as being held or worn), else it will return 0.0.

rows.Name: query.is_cooldown_type
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns 1.0 if the specified held or worn item has the specified cooldown type name, otherwise returns 0.0. First argument is the cooldown name to check for, second argument is the equipment slot name, and optional third argument is the numerical slot id. For second and third arguments, uses the same name and id that the replaceitem command takes when querying entities.

rows.Name: query.relative_block_has_all_tags
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes an entity-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has all of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.relative_block_has_any_tag
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Takes an entity-relative position and one or more tag names, and returns either 0 or 1 based on if the block at that position has any of the tags provided.

rows.Name: query.scoreboard
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) DEPRECATED (The coming Actor Property feature will replace the need for querying hidden scoreboard data. Current client-side scoreboard code is only meant for supporting the standard UI elements.) Takes one argument - the name of the scoreboard entry for this entity.  Returns the specified scoreboard value for this entity.

rows.Name: query.self
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the current entity.

rows.Name: query.target
rows.Description: (EXPERIMENTAL. Enable 'Molang Features' to use.) Returns the target of the current entity if one exists.

sections.name: Experimental Operators
content: Some operators may be behind experimental gameplay toggles (see list below).  After getting feedback, we can adjust them further or move them into general availability.

sections.name: Versioned Changes
content: Molang uses the `"min_engine_version"` from the `manifest.json` of the resource or behavior pack that contains each Molang expression to determine which version of the rules to apply. This allows for changes to how Molang works without breaking existing content.
Molang Versioned Change versions apply to each expression separately, so it's possible to have different versions active if multiple packs are loaded.
This is a list of the Versioned Changes that have been added, along with the corresponding game version.

To know which Versioned Changes are in effect, look at the `"min_engine_version"` of the `manifest.json` of the resource or behavior pack that contains your Molang expression. Any Versioned Change with a version less than or equal to that version number will be in effect.

rows.Description: Initial support for Versioned Changes added. (Not actually a Versioned Change)

Fixed query.item_remaining_use_duration conversion from ticks to seconds (multiplied by 20 instead of dividing). Also fixed normalization logic in that query to go from 1 down to 0 instead of 0 up to 1.
Added some new error messages for invalid expressions which previously ran with probably unexpected results. For example "'text' + 1" will now cause a content error.
Added error detection for too many operators in parentheses or brackets, for example: `1+(2 3)`. Also added more explicit error detection for when an unknown token is encountered.

Fixed conditional (ternary) operator associativity. Previously nested conditional expressions like `A ? B : C ? D : E` would evaluate as `(A ? B : C) ? D : E`. Now they evaluate as `A ? B : (C ? D : E)`.

Fixed Logical AND to evaluate before Logical OR, and for comparison operators to evaluate before equality operators. For example `A && B || C` now evaluates as `(A && B) || C` instead of `A && (B || C)`. And `A < B == C > D` now evalutes as `(A < B) == (C > D)` instead of `((A < B) == C) > D`.
Fixed error where dividing by a dynamically determined negative variable resulted in a division by the absolute (positive) value of the number instead.
Fixed query.cape_flap_amount using the wrong player rotation (head rotation instead of body rotation).
